journal-meta.journal-title: Journal of Intelligent Material Systems and Structures

title-group.article-title: Coupling of hierarchical piezoelectric plate finite elements via Arlequin method

article-meta.aff: 1Centre de Recherche Public Henri Tudor, Luxembourg-Kirchberg, Luxembourg

author-notes.corresp: Salim Belouettar, Department of Advanced Materials and Structures, Centre de Recherche Public Henri Tudor, 29 Avenue John F. Kennedy, L-1855 Luxembourg-Kirchberg, Luxembourg. Email: salim.belouettar@tudor.lu

abstract.p: Coupling of piezoelectric plate elements based on different through-the-thickness expansions and variational principles through the Arlequin method is proposed in this article. Computational cost is reduced assuming refined models only in those zones of the structure where high accuracy is needed. Piezoelectric finite elements are formulated on the basis of a unified formulation. Higher order, layer-wise and mixed finite elements are easily obtained via unified formulation. This formulation is extended to the Arlequin method in the piezoelectric context to derive matrices related to coupling zones. Two electro-mechanical coupling operators are proposed. Multilayered plates are investigated. Numerical results show that the Arlequin method in the context of unified formulation couples sub-domains having different piezoelectric finite elements effectively.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: Smart structures represent the next-generation design in the aerospace industry. Piezoelectric materials are extensively used in this context as sensors and actuators thanks to the so-called direct and inverse effect, respectively. Layers of piezoelectric ceramics can be integrated directly in multilayered plates or can be surface bonded. The analysis and design of such structures are cumbersome subjects. Accurate results require refined models that are computationally expensive. This article proposes a methodology to strike a balance between accuracy and computational cost: a refined model is adopted only for specific portions of the plate, which are coupled to the remaining parts, modelled through less refined and computationally cheaper theories, via the Arlequin method. A brief discussion about piezoelectric plate formulations and computational techniques to couple different domains is described in the following. In the review article by Saravanos and Heyliger (1999), several laminate theories, analytical solutions and numerical solutions have been taken into account for laminates with piezoelectric actuators or sensors. Benjeddou (2000) presented a survey on finite elements (FEs) for adaptive structural elements. Common assumptions in the formulation of piezoelectric elements, such as through-the-thickness linear variation of the electric potential, have been analysed and their limitations are pointed out. Several plate FEs have been considered, both with and without electric degrees of freedom. In most cases, the latter adopt an equivalent single layer (ESL) model. The piezoelectric effect is included via its equivalent electric load or the converse constitutive equations. Wang and Yang’s (2000) review considers higher order theories in a systematic way, according to the through-the-thickness interpolation of displacement components and electric potential in the plate. Auricchio et al. (2001) developed a FE for piezoelectric plates based on a Reissner-Mindlin-type modelling. Sheikh et al. (2001) proposed a finite element model (FEM) based on first-order shear deformation theory (FSDT) description for the mechanical part with layer-wise (LW) electric potential. Sze et al. (2004) took into account piecewise constant and piecewise linear assumptions on the spatial distributions of the electric variables. Thornburgh and Chattopadhyay (2002) adopted a third-order theory to develop a general framework for coupled piezoelectric–mechanical plate problems. Robbins and Chopra (2006) examined the effect of the mesh density, the transverse kinematic assumption, the adhesive bond layer thickness and the span-to-thickness ratio on the global response of a plate actuated via piezoelectric patches. Mechanical variable kinematic FE is adopted, since an induced strain approach is used. A similar analysis in terms of strain energy distribution is carried out by Robbins and Chopra (2007). A condensed notation known as unified formulation (UF) was adopted by Carrera and Nali (2010) to derive FEs with variable kinematic for multifield problems. D’Ottavio and Kroplin (2006) presented an extension of the Reissner mixed variational theorem (RMVT) to multifield problems, in particular for multilayered structures embedding piezoelectric layers. Carrera and Nali (2009) proposed a FE formulation based on RMVT modified to account for interlaminar continuous transverse electric displacement, named RMVT-Dz. A reliable prediction of the transverse electric displacement is necessary for the calculation of the electric charge, which is important for the development of robust control algorithms. A particular form of RMVT (RMVT-Dz-σn) was considered by Carrera et al. (2010) to a priori fulfil the interlaminar continuity of transverse electro-mechanical variables.

Several numerical methods have been formulated in the last years to couple ‘refined’ and ‘coarse’ sub-domains of a structure. The following methods can be addressed as mono-model methods, that is, the kinematic assumptions hold on the entire model. In the sequential adaptation methods, structure’s sub-domains differ in degrees of freedom of the shape functions (p-adaptation, Szabo and Babuska, 1991) or mesh size (h-adaptation, Bank, 1983), or both (hp-adaptation, Bathe, 1996). In the multi-grid method (Fish et al., 1996), coarse and fine meshes share information inside an iterative algorithm. In the case of multi-model methods, structure’s sub-domains may differ in the kinematic assumptions. In the s-version method (Fish, 1992; Fish and Markolefas, 1993), incompatible meshes (different element sizes and polynomial orders) with a local–global border are coupled. Reddy and Robbins (1994) and Reddy (2004) presented a multi-model method based on a variable kinematic theory and on mesh superposition in the sense of Fish (1992) and Fish and Markolefas (1993), where FSDT variables are coupled. Robbins and Reddy (1996) adopt the same strategy in the analysis of a plate with surface-bonded actuators. The plate is loaded by inducing an in-plane strain field in the piezoelectric actuator, being the electric field not explicitly accounted for. In the three-field formulation by Brezzi and Marini (2005), an additional grid at the interface is introduced. The unknowns are represented independently in each sub-domain and on the interface, the matching being provided by the suitable Lagrange multipliers. Ben Dhia (1998, 1999) and Ben Dhia and Rateau (2005) proposed the Arlequin method. The coupling among different numerical models is obtained through the Lagrange multipliers. Biscani et al. (2011, in press) adopted the Arlequin method to model beam mechanics through variable kinematic beam theories and plate mechanics via hierarchical plate theories.

In the present work, the Arlequin method is formulated in the context of the plate unified approach by Carrera (1995) for piezoelectric problems. Among the sub-domains to be coupled, the FEs may differ by through-the-thickness description and by variational principle. Non-conforming meshes are not considered. Refined elements are employed in the portion of the structure in which less refined theories would yield inaccurate results. Two electro-mechanical coupling operators, formulated on the basis of the well-known mechanical ones, are proposed. Multilayer plates with piezoelectric layers and patches are taken into account. The proposed approach is validated towards mono-model results and three-dimensional (3D) results. Accurate results have been obtained with a significant reduction of the total number of degrees of freedom.

sec.title: Hierarchical piezoelectric plate theories
sec.p:
In this section, the UF by Carrera is presented (Carrera, 1995; Carrera and Nali, 2010). UF allows obtaining several two-dimensional models thanks to the separation of the unknown variables into a set of thickness functions depending only upon the through-the-thickness coordinate
z
and the corresponding variables depending upon the in-plane coordinates
( x , y )
. The governing equations are written in terms of a fundamental nucleo that does not depend on the through-the-thickness expansion order and the variables description that can be ESL or LW.
a ( x , y , z )
, and its virtual variation
δ a ( x , y , z )
can be written according to the following general expansion

where
F
τ
is a generic through-the-thickness expansion function,
a
is a generic primary variables and
N
is the order of the theory. The summing convention with repeated indexes
τ
and
s
is assumed.
N
is as high as 4. In a ESL approach, the unknowns are assumed globally for the whole structure. Within UF, Maclaurin’s polynomials are adopted as thickness functions
F
τ
. For LW models, unknowns are considered independently in each layer. The thickness functions are a linear combination of Legendre’s polynomials (Carrera, 2003) and vary versus a local through-the-thickness dimensionless coordinate. The thickness functions have been chosen in order to ensure congruence and equilibrium at layers’ interface.

A system of acronyms is required for addressing the two-dimensional models that can be obtained via UF. The first letter indicates the multilayer approach and can be either ‘E’ for an ESL approach or ‘L’ for a LW approach. The second letter refers to the primary unknowns: ‘D’ stands for PVD-based models and ‘M’ for mixed theories. A number indicates the order of expansion. Summarising, ‘ED1’–‘ED4’ are linear to fourth-order, ESL, PVD-based models, and ‘EM1’–‘EM4’ are ESL, mixed models. The equivalent LW models are ‘LD1’–‘LD4’ and ‘LM1’–‘LM4’.

An exhaustive description of the derivation of FE matrices can be found in the literature (Carrera, 2003; Carrera and Nali, 2009; Demasi and Carrera, 2002). Primary unknowns vector
a

This set is composed of equilibrium equations and, only in the case of mixed variational statements, compatibility equations for transverse strains.

The complete derivation of the nuclei can be found in Carrera and Nali (2009, 2010) and Carrera et al. (2010). As far as the whole structure is concerned, the FEM problem in the framework of the proposed UF is governed by the following equations

Four-node quadrilateral element is considered in this work. Shear locking is addressed via reduced integration of the shape functions
N
i
and their derivatives: one Gauss point is considered for each element instead of
2 × 2
Gauss points. A exhaustive discussion on the different numerical integration schemes and techniques to contrast shear locking in multilayered plate elements can be found in Carrera et al. (2010).

sec.title: Arlequin method in the context of UF
sec.p:
Plate’s volume (
V
) is divided into two sub-domains
A
1
and
A
2
that are partially overlapped.
S
represents the overlapping volume. For each sub-domain, a different model is assumed

being
ξ
a dummy index that counts the sub-domains. The global electro-mechanical problem is solved merging together the two sub-domains via the Arlequin method. The internal and external virtual works are computed for each sub-domain. The structural integrity in the overlapping volume is ensured via a Lagrangian multiplier field (
λ

C
ξ
), which link the degrees of freedom of each subdomain within the overlapping volume. The generic variational principle becomes

ξ
should be such that the sub-domain with a more accurate description has a higher weight in the global equilibrium (Ben Dhia and Rateau, 2005). In this work, a constant value equal to 0.98 is assumed for the sub-domain in which the refined model is adopted. The virtual external work is treated in a similar manner. The displacement fields and the electric potential field are considered in the virtual coupling work

According to Ben Dhia (1999) and Guidault and Belytschko (2007), the same approximation order should be assumed for the less refined model and the Lagrangian multiplier to avoid a locking phenomena, which arises when the approximation of the more refined model is adopted. Considering the whole structure and assuming that the refined model is adopted in the sub-domain
A
2
, the governing equations of the variable kinematic problem are

Coupling is performed considering only the displacement fields and the electric potential distribution. The fundamental nucleo of the coupling matrix is, therefore, a
4 × 4
array in the case of PVD-based models as detailed in equations (25) or (27). It is extended with zeros to a
4 × 5
array in case of RMVT-Dz and to a
4 × 8
array in case of RMVT-Dz-σn.

sec.title: Numerical results and discussion
sec.p: Solutions adopting the classical coupling operators are first addressed. Mechanical plates subjected to localised transverse pressure and a narrow plate actuated via a piezoelectric finite patch are presented. The proposed electro-mechanical coupling operators are then addressed. The Heyliger plate, both in sensor and in actuator configuration, is considered. The accuracy of the variable kinematics solutions is assessed towards the corresponding mono-model results and towards 3D FE or exact solutions. The effect of the choice of the coupling operator is investigated.

sec.title: Mechanical plate
sec.p:
The considered plate is square (
a = 0 . 1
m
) and simply supported. Aspect ratios length-over-thickness
a / h = 10
and
a / h = 40
are considered. The plate undergoes a localised transverse pressure (
P
) equal to 1 MPa applied on a square region with edge equal to
a / 5
located at the centre of the top surface (see Figure 1). A symmetric
[ 0 / 90 / 0 ]
and an antisymmetric
[ 90 / 0
]
2
configurations are considered. The stacking sequence starts from the plate top; ply angles are measured with respect to the x-axis. All the layers are of the same fibre-reinforced material (see Table 1). Because of symmetries, only a quarter of the plate is taken into account. Results are compared to a 3D exact solution based upon Pagano’s (1970) solution, where the localised loading is approximated by a Fourier expansion with 101 terms. This value ensures a convergence of the shear stress with four significant digits.

caption.p: Coupling between the two sub-domains and applied load.

sec.p:
Mesh convergence for the transverse displacement
u
z
at
x = y = a / 2
at the bottom of the
[ 0 / 90 / 0 ]
plate with
a / h = 10
is shown in Figure 2. In the following, mono-model results are computed with a regular mesh of 10 × 10 quadrilateral elements. In the case of the Arlequin results, refined part is at the centre of the plate. It is square and consists of 5 × 5 elements. A minimum superposition volume is considered, as shown in Figure 1. The coupling operators adopted are the classical ones since the problem is purely mechanical. They can be retrieved from equations (19) and (20) neglecting the electric quantities. Similarly, two variational principles are considered: PVD and RMVT-σn. They can be retrieved neglecting the electric quantities in equations (5) and (8), respectively. In the case of
H
1
coupling,
l
~
depends on the extension of the superposition zone according to Guidault and Belytschko (2007);
l
~
=
l
el
is adopted, where
l
el
is the element’s side length.

sec.p:
Results for the
[ 0 / 90 / 0 ]
plate and the
[ 90 / 0
]
2
plate are presented in Tables 2 and 3, respectively. Normal stress
σ
xx
and transverse displacement
u
z
are computed at plate centre at the bottom of the laminate. Out-of-plane shear stress
σ
xz
is evaluated at
x / a = 3 / 8
,
y / b = 1 / 2
and
z = 0
. The coupling operator
L
2
is adopted. In the case of the
[ 90 / 0
]
2
plate, the out-of-plane shear stress
σ
xz
is computed at the bottom of the second layer and at the top of the third one to highlight the fulfilment of the through-the-thickness equilibrium requirement in mixed models. ESL models are less accurate for thick plates (
a / h = 10
) than for thin plates (
a / h = 40
). LW theories should be adopted to compute shear stresses accurately. Variable kinematic results for stresses match the corresponding mono-model results, proving the effectiveness of the Arlequin method in merging domains having FEs based on different theories. The accuracy of the shear stresses in the variable kinematic solutions is higher when the refined sub-domain adopts a mixed model than when it adopts a PVD-based model. Out-of-plane shear stress
σ
xz
computed at
x / a = 3 / 8
,
y / b = 1 / 2
across the thickness of the plates is presented in Figure 3 for
a / h = 10
. The coupling operator
H
1
is adopted. LW mixed models guarantee the continuity of the shear stress across the layers. Variable kinematic results match the mixed models ones. Further results on the coupling of hierarchical mechanical plate elements can be found in Biscani et al. (in press).

sec.title: Narrow plate actuated via piezoelectric finite patch
sec.p:
A narrow plate in aluminium (
E = 73
GPa
,
ν = 0 . 34
), clamped on one side, is considered. Plate’s in-plane dimensions along the x- and y-axes are
a = 0 . 1
m
and
b = 0 . 01
m
, respectively. Its thickness is
0 . 002
m
. A piezoelectric finite patch (see Table 1 for the material properties) is bonded at the top surface of the plate near its clamped side, as shown in Figure 4. Patch’s in-plane dimensions are
0 . 01 × 0 . 01
m
and its thickness is
0 . 001
m
. An electric potential equal to
1
V
is prescribed at the top surface of the piezoelectric patch. Null electric potential is assigned at its bottom surface.

caption.p: Clamped narrow plate actuated by a piezoelectric patch.

sec.p:
Mono-model solutions are obtained with a regular mesh of
60 × 1
LW piezoelectric elements, assuming two computational layers for the plate. In the variable kinematic solutions, an ESL mechanical model is adopted in the sub-domain
A
2
(see Figure 4). The refined sub-domain
A
1
consists of
12 × 1
LW piezoelectric elements. Only one element is superposed. Coupling is achieved via the classical coupling operators since in the superposition volume the electric field is not present. Reference results are obtained via the commercial FE software ABAQUS. Piezoelectric 3D FE C3D20RE (see SIMULIA, 2005) has been adopted, and convergence of transverse displacements within
1 %
has been obtained with a progressive refinement of the mesh.

Results are presented in Table 4. Transverse displacement
u
z
is computed on the mid-plane at the centre of the plate and at
x = a ,
y = b / 2
. Higher order LW models underestimate the reference solution by about
6 %
. The two coupling operators yield similar results. Variable kinematic solutions match the corresponding mono-model solutions: the mechanics of the plate far from the actuator is correctly modelled by an ESL mechanical theory, whereas the actuation of the patch requires a LW piezoelectric theory to be accurately described. The variation of
u
z
along the x-axis for
y = b / 2
at the top of the plate is presented in Figure 5. The coupling operator
H
1
is adopted. The bending induced by the piezoelectric patch can be noticed in the sub-domain
A
1
.

at mid-plane of the actuated narrow plate.

sec.title: Heyliger plate
sec.p:
A simply supported cross-ply
[ 0 / 90 ]
laminate composed of elastic fibre-reinforced material with piezoelectric layer bonded at the top and at the bottom surfaces is considered. Materials’ properties are presented in Table 1. The plate is square with side length
a
equal to 4 m. Total thickness is 1 m: each piezoelectric layer accounts for
10 %
and each elastic layer accounts for
40 %
of total thickness. Two set of boundary conditions and loadings are considered: the sensor case and the actuator case (see Figure 6). RMVT-Dz-σn-based models are identified by the superscript
a
and RMVT-Dz-based models by the superscript
b
. Results are compared with the exact 3D solutions provided by Heyliger (1994). Only a quarter of the plate is taken into account in the models. Mesh convergence for the transverse displacement
u
z
at
x = y = a / 2
at plate mid-plane is shown in Figure 7 both for the sensor and for the actuator case. The convergence of the RMVT-Dz-σn-based solution in the actuator configuration is very fast: in many cases, FEs based on mixed variational statements assure better convergence than PVD-based ones. In the following, mono-model results are evaluated with a mesh of 10 × 10 quadrilateral elements. The Arlequin results adopt a square refined region of 5 × 5 elements at the centre of the plate, as shown in Figure 8.

caption.p: Heyliger plate in (a) sensor configuration and (b) actuator configuration.

Convergence of the transverse displacement
u
z
versus the number of elements for the Heyliger plate in the (a) sensor case and (b) actuator case.
Coupling between the two sub-domains with (a) minimum superposition volume and (b) extended superposition volume.

sec.title: Comparison between the electro-mechanical coupling operators
sec.p:
In the sensor case, a double sinusoidal pressure is applied on the top surface of the plate (see Figure 6(a)). Its amplitude is 1 Pa. Top and bottom surfaces are fixed at zero potential. Two superposition zones, denominated minimum and extended, are considered, as shown in Figure 8. In the superposition volume, two solutions that do not necessarily match exist. The electro-mechanical coupling operators in equations (19) and (20) are adopted.
l
~
=
l
el
is considered in the case of minimum superposition and
l
~
= 3
l
el
in the case of extended superposition. Coupling between LD2- and LD4-based FEs is adopted and results are compared with LD4 mono-model solutions. Results for primary variables are very similar for both the coupling operator and superposition volume. They match the mono-model solutions. Transverse displacement
u
z
variation along the x-axis for
y = a / 2
at the top of the plate is presented in Figure 9 in the case of minimum superposition volume and
H
1
coupling operator. Figure 10 shows the variation of the electric potential
ϕ
at plate mid-plane with extended superposition and
L
2
coupling operator. Variable kinematic results match the mono-model results: the proposed electro-mechanical operators couple effectively the two sub-domains. The influence of the choice of the coupling operator and the superposition extension is presented in Figure 11 for the stress component
σ
xx
. It is computed along the x-axis for
y = a / 2
at the top of the plate. Difference between the results is greater in the superposition zone. In the following, the reduced superposition volume is adopted in order to reduce the total number of degrees of freedom.

sec.title: Comparison with exact results in sensor case
sec.p:
Loads and boundary conditions are as in section ‘Comparison between the electro-mechanical coupling operators’ (see Figure 6(a)). Tables 5, 6 and 7 present the electric potential, the transverse normal stress and the transverse electric displacement, respectively. Results are computed at the centre of the plate across it thickness. Mono-model solutions are based on PVD (LD1), RMVT-Dz (LM3b) and RMVT-Dz-σn (LM3a). Variable kinematic solutions couple PVD- and RMVT-Dz-based sub-domains (LD1–LM3b) and PVD- and RMVT-Dz-σn-based sub-domains (LD1–LM3a). The number of degrees of freedom is reduced by more than 35%. In Table 5, higher order models match the exact solution. Electric potential is accurately predicted by variable kinematic models, whereas LD1 mono-model provides inaccurate results in the piezoelectric layers. Table 6 shows that an accurate prediction of transverse normal stress requires a RMVT-Dz-σn-based model. LD1–LM3a results match the RMVT-Dz-σn-based mono-model solution. RMVT-based models are mandatory for the computation of the transverse electric displacement, as shown in Table 7. Both the transverse quantities
σ
zz
and Dz are not accurately computed in the case of variable kinematic solution LD1–LM3b with
H
1
coupling (see Tables 6 and 7). The inaccuracy is probably due to the derivatives of displacement and electric potential in the coupling operator (see equation (22)). LD1 sub-model is not refined enough to compute accurately these values. If a second-order model is adopted as less refined sub-model results are accurate with the
H
1
coupling, as shown in Table 8. Mid-plane transverse displacement at the centre of the plate is presented in Table 9. LM3a results match the reference solution. All the considered solutions are accurate. Figure 12 presents the variation of
D
z
at the centre of the plate across its thickness. LM4b mono-model result matches the exact reference solution, whereas LD2 mono-model overestimates it by about 20%. Arlequin results are obtained with LM4b as refined model (sub-domain A2) and LD2 in sub-domain A1 using the coupling operator
L
2
. Arlequin results match LM4b mono-model results and the exact solution. With respect to LM4b mono-model, the total number of degrees of freedom is reduced by about 36%.

caption.p:
Transverse electric displacement at the centre of the Heyliger plate with
H
1
coupling operator.
Heyliger plate, sensor case—electrical potential at the centre of the plate across its thickness.

Heyliger plate, sensor case—transverse electric displacement at the centre of the plate across its thickness.

Heyliger plate, sensor case—transverse normal stress and transverse electric displacement at the centre of the plate across its thickness,
H
1
coupling operator.
Mid-plane transverse displacement at the centre of the Heyliger plate.

sec.title: Comparison with exact results in actuator case
sec.p:
In the actuator case, a double sinusoidal electric potential is applied on the top surface of the plate (see Figure 6(b)). Its amplitude is
1
V
, and the bottom surface is fixed at zero potential. Mid-plane transverse displacement at the centre of the plate is presented in Table 9. LD1 overestimates the reference solution by about 6%. Variable kinematic results follow closely the corresponding mono-model solutions in the case of
L
2
coupling. Values with
H
1
are higher than with the corresponding mono-models: as already observed in Guidault and Belytschko (2007), the relation in equation (22) enforced by
H
1
may induce a displacement shift between the sub-domains, which can be problematic when bending mechanics is predominant. This is especially true if the less refined sub-model does not accurately model the mechanics of the structure, as it is the case of LD1. When LD2 sub-model is adopted, results with the two coupling operators are similar. Table 10 presents
σ
xx
computed at the centre of the plate across it thickness. LD1 results are inaccurate, in particular in the top piezoelectric layer. Higher order mono-models follow closely the reference solution, and variable kinematic solutions match the corresponding mono-models results.

caption.p: Heyliger plate, actuator case—in-plane normal stress at the centre of the plate across its thickness.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p:
Hierarchical piezoelectric plate FEs have been coupled in the context of the Arlequin method. In order to reduce the computational cost, refined FEs have been employed only in certain sub-domains of the structure. Plate theories are based on a UF that yields the element stiffness matrix in a compact form that does not depend upon the order of the theories. Refined models that account for transverse electric displacement can be formulated straightforwardly. Arlequin coupling matrix has been obtained in the framework of the proposed UF as a fundamental nucleo. Two electro-mechanical coupling operators for piezoelectric problems have been proposed. Results have been validated towards mono-models results and 3D approximate and exact solutions. The Arlequin method with the proposed electro-mechanical coupling operators proves to be an effective approach to couple sub-domains of the structure modelled with piezoelectric FEs having different primary unknowns’ expansions. Coupling based on the displacements and electrical potential among RMVT-D3, RMVT-D3-σn- and PVD-based models proved to be effective. If the less refined sub-domain does not model with sufficient accuracy strain and electric field components, the
H
1
electro-mechanical coupling should be avoided. Accurate results have been obtained in the refined part of the model with a significant reduction of the total number of degrees of freedom.
